occurrences.line_text: But sigh't and sorrow'd for her louer deare,
Ne lightned was with window, nor with louer,
The which her lauish louers to her gaue;
And by my wretched louers side me pight,
And could not lacke her louers company,
Here take thy louers token on thy pate.
As miserable louers vse to rew,
That idle name of loue, and louers life,
Wherewith she makes her louers drunken mad,
Does charme her louers, and the feeble sprightes
Thereby more louers vnto her to call;
Apes, Lions, ï¿½/-gles, Owles, fooles, louers, children, Dames.
Whylome her louers, which her lusts did feed,
Another arrow hath your louers hart to hit.
So straungely vewed her straunge louers shade,
Thou then shalt make, t'increase thy louers pray.
Her louers shape, and cheualrous aray;
And called is by her lost louers name,
To which sad louers were transformd of yore;
Who louers will deceiue. Thus was the ape,
Now making layes of loue and louers paine,
Darke was the Euening, fit for louers stealth,
And ranne into her louers armes right fast;
Of louers loosely knit, where list them to repaire.
High heauen beholds sad louers nightly theeueryes.
Thus doe those louers with sweet counteruayle,
And magnifying louers deare debate;
That crowne true louers with immortall blis,
Of louers sad calamities of old,
Some of deare louers, foes perpetuall:
And all true louers with dishonor blotten,
And those two Ladies their two louers deare,
Amongst her louers, and great quarrels wrought,
That since their days such louers were not found elswhere.
And with lewd termes their louers to deface.
For louers heauen must passe by sorrowes hell.
Her captiue louers friend, young Placidas:
And louers life forth set.
Delightfull bowres, to solace louers trew;
And therein thousand payres of louers walkt,
Of louers lincked in true harts consent;
The which sad louers for their vowes did pay;
And in them bore true louers vowes entire:
Great sorts of louers piteously complayning,
Of all her louers, which would her haue reft.
Then let mee liue, as louers ought to do,
And learne to loue, by learning louers paines to rew.
She chaw'd the cud of louers carefull plight;
Were best deuise for this your louers smart,
The more would wretched louers her adore.
Vnto the which all louers doe resort,
He which doth summon louers to Loues iudgement hall.
Me list not die for any louers doole:
Thus I triumphed long in louers paine,
That enuies louers long prosperity,
Fierce warres and faithfull loues shall moralize my song.
In loues and gentle iollities arrayd,
And made him dreame of loues and lustfull play,
Like a young Squire, in loues and lusty-hed
And her due loues deriu'd to that vile witches share.
If from their loyall loues he might then moue;
Old loues, and warres for Ladies doen by many a Lord.
The forlorne mayd did with loues longing burne,
The wanton loues of false Fidessa faire,
His loues and lignage Arthur tells
True Loues are ofte[n] sown, but seldom grow on ground.
So diuersly discoursing of their loues,
As for loose loues they are vaine, and vanish into nought.
Or wrapped be in loues of former Dame,
The vsuall ioyes at knitting of loues band.
Fit to inflame faire Lady with loues rage,
And losse of loue, to her that loues to liue,
These two gay knights, vowd to so diuerse loues,
And by the loues, which were to them most deare,
As euer of their loues they would be glad.
And those two froward sisters, their faire loues
Ne Ladies loues, ne sweete entreaties might
And is for Venus loues renowmed more,
Of highest God, that loues his creatures so,
But in lewd loues, and wastfull luxuree,
Then losse of loue to him, that loues but one;
Hath me subiected to loues cruell law:
Dy, who so list for him, he was loues enimy.
Yet she loues none but one, that Marinell is hight.
Of gods high prayse, and of their loues sweet teene,
And in her litle loues stead, which was strayd,
And their true loues without suspition tell abrode.
His feeble hart wide launched with loues cruell wound.
The witches sonne loues Florimell:
Fraile Ladies hart with loues consuming rage,
That loues his fetters, though they were of gold.
Till that prickt forth with loues extremitie,
where Loues spoyles are exprest.
A lay of loues delight, with sweet consent:
Of his loues succour, of his owne redresse,
Each other of loues bitter fruit despoile.
So none should be out shut, sith all of loues were fitted.
Where all that night they of their loues did treat,
And loues another, with whom now she go'th
And with their honours and their loues regard,
And those two Ladies, their two loues vnseene;
And afterwards did for her loues first hire,
This mischiefe framd, for their first loues defeature,
Thereby to make their loues beginning, their liues end.
Fearing least she your loues away should woo,
The Squire her loues, and being blam'd
He liues (quoth he) and his ï¿½mylia loues.
Yet with lewd loues and lust intemperate
To seeke their loues dispersed diuersly,
And also of their priuate loues beguyled;
That of their loues choise they might freedom clame,
Ne euer ought but of their true loues talkt,
Their spotlesse pleasures, and sweet loues content.
Whose liues although decay'd, yet loues decayed neuer.
Might frankely there their loues desire possesse;
A flocke of litle loues, and sports, and ioyes,
Some of their losse, some of their loues delay,
Amongst the rest some one through loues constrayning,
And she that vertue loues and vice detests
That loues not me, then doe it not prolong,
To meeke obeysance of loues mightie raine,
Touching her loues successe, her lingring smart.
That no new loues impression euer could
Such was this Ladies fit, in her loues fond accusing.
But in reuenge both of her loues distresse,
For his loues sake his Lions skin vndight:
To fly his stepdames loues outrageous,
Litae, by him begot in loues delight,
Of their franke loues, free from all gealous spyes:
My loues owne part to leaue so suddenly,
For Ladies seruice, and for loues delight,
And troubled had their quiet loues delight.
for loues disdaine decreed.
That of their loues successe they there may make report.
In wich the names of all loues folke were fyled,
Or kept in bands, or from their loues exyled,
He which doth summon louers to Loues iudgement hall.
Till she had sau'd so many loues, as she did lose.
and loues fayre Pastorell;
His layes, his loues, his lookes she did them all despize.
Thus to bereaue thy Loues deare sight from thee:
His Loues deare spoile, in which his heart was prayde,
Fit to keepe sheepe, vnfit for loues content:
A loue-sick hart, she did to him enuy;
Her loue-sicke hart to other thoughts did steale;
Through stubborne handling of her loue-sicke hart;
A thousand feares, that loue-sicke fancies faine to fynde.
And Night, the patronesse of loue-stealth faire,
To her I sing of loue, that loueth best,
Of all her passed paines: one louing howre
And fortunes tell, and read in louing bookes,
Haue wasted, louing him with all my powre,
His louing mother came vpon a day
Her mighty charmes, her furious louing fit,
Whilest louing thou mayst loued be with equall crime.
Could iudge what paines do louing harts perplexe.
The louing mother, that nine monethes did beare,
Else shall thy louing Lord thee see no more,
But from her louing side the tender babes to take.
To whom her louing hart she linked fast
And found such fauour in their louing hartes,
The louing couple need no reskew feare,
To ioylesse dread, and mak'st the louing hart
In stead thereof know, that your louing Make,
That liuing thus, a wretch and louing so,
And if ye deeme me death for louing one,
To take Briana for his louing fere,
And sacred Peace shall louingly perswade
Either embracing other louingly,
And euery loup fast lockt, as fearing foes despight.
And at them both Sir Paridell did loure.
Where Calidore was present, he would loure,
Which lou'st the shadow of a warlike knight;
The Porter eke to her did lout with humble gestes.
I ioy to see you lout so low on ground,
Yet much disdaining vnto him to lout,
Ne none disdained low to him to lout:
That Ladies part, and to the Souldan lout:
Vnto thy loue, that made thee low to lout;
He humbly louted in meeke lowlinesse,
And comming him before, low louted on the lay.
But to him louted low, and greeted goodly well.
He louted lowly, as did him becum,
And friskt, and flong aloft, and louted low on knee.
Together with the king of Louthiane,
He faire the knight saluted, louting low,
Tho to him louting lowly, did begin
Did spend her dayes, and lov'd in forests wyld to space.
Gather the Rose of love, whilest yet is time,
Vnder a vele, that wimpled was full low,
He faire the knight saluted, louting low,
And low, where dawning day doth neuer peepe,
And to your mighty will. Her humblesse low
With loftie eyes, halfe loth to looke so low,
Low vnder all, yet aboue all in pride,
And all his sences stound, that still he lay full low.
High ouer hils, and low adowne the dale,
And scaly tayle was stretcht adowne his backe full low.
That to the ground it doubleth him full low
His dwelling is low in a valley greene,
And wasted life do lye in ashes low.
His dwelling has, low in an hollow caue,
That cursed man, low sitting on the ground,
Hight Humiltï¿½. They passe in stouping low;
For as the tree does fall, so lyes it euer low.
And pyn'd his flesh, to keepe his body low and chast.
At last low stouping with vnweldie sway,
And him before themselues prostrating low,
And bowed low, that her right well became,
And on the ground her selfe prostrating low,
But they him layd full low in dungeon deepe,
And after gaue a grone so deepe and low,
Beside a bubbling fountaine low she lay,
Then casting vp a deadly looke, full low,
And low behinde her backe were scattered:
Wrath, gelosie, griefe, loue this Squire haue layd thus low.
So him dismounted low, he did compell
Should him dismay, and make him stoup so low,
That streight on ground made him full low to lye;
That hath (maugre her spight) thus low me laid in dust.
And low abase the high heroicke spright,
Sometimes to him, that low in dust doth ly?
Those that were vp themselues, kept others low,
Those that were low themselues, held others hard,
Like a great water flood, that tombling low
Low his lasciuious armes adown did creepe,
Then th'one her selfe low ducked in the flood,
Vp in one knot, he low adowne did lose:
The gentle warbling wind low answered to all.
To make his wonne, low vnderneath the ground,
But standing high aloft, low lay thine eare,
And from his loftie steed dismounting low,
That made him low incline his lofty crest,
The third a Damzell was of low degree,
She low let fall, that flowd from her lanck syde
And in thine ashes buried low dost lie,
And comming him before, low louted on the lay.
Was all abasht, and low prostrating, said;
But to him louted low, and greeted goodly well.
I ioy to see you lout so low on ground,
But like a wide deepe poke, downe hanging low,
Yet was he but a Squire of low degree;
He bowed low, and so a while did lie:
This louely swaine the Squire of low degree;
And told his Dame, her Squire of low degree
The Squire of low degree releast
Amongst the rest, that Squire of low degree
But from my lofty steede dismounting low,
Crept in by stouping low, or stealing of the kaies.
Low looking dales, disloignd from common gaze;
Enwouen was with gold, that raught full low a downe.
Ne none disdained low to him to lout:
And let their swelling waters low before him fall.
And friskt, and flong aloft, and louted low on knee.
Amongst them all she placed him most low,
And her proud person low prostrated on the plaine.
Who bowing low before her Maiestie,
And low dismounting from his loftie steede,
And laid his Seneschall low on the ground,
But Belge with her sonnes prostrated low
Yet so from low to high vplifted is your fame.
Or low beneath, yet ought they well to know
That armed knight, that low on ground he lay;
Whether high towring, or accoasting low,
From pitch of higher place, vnto this low degree.
From so high step to stoupe vnto so low.
Vnto thy loue, that made thee low to lout;
We should our selues demeane, to low, to hie;
Of good and bad alike, of low and hie;
The lookers on, and lowd to him gan call
That roaring all with rage, did lowd requere
Through which he sent his voyce, and lowd did call
And to his Lord and Ladie lowd gan call,
And to Diana calling lowd for ayde,
Her lowd gainsaid, and both their champions bad
And crying Mercy lowd, his pitious hands gan reare.
And with big thundring voyce reuyld him lowd;
For very felnesse lowd he gan to weepe,
The watch, and lowd vnto the knights did call,
His larumbell might lowd and wide be hard,
And lowd to them for succour called euermore.
The whiles sweet Zephirus lowd whisteled
The wofull husbandman doth lowd complaine,
And with it bound the beast, that lowd did rore
He rau'd, he wept, he stampt, he lowd did cry,
Seemd that lowde thunder with amazement great
Lowde shriking him afflicted to the very sowle.
Then gan he lowdly through the house to call:
That with the vncouth smart the Monster lowdly cryde.
He lowdly brayd, that like was neuer heard,
Fiercely approching, to him lowdly cride,
He lowdly gan to laugh, and thus to iest;
Where that same Damzell lowdly him bespake,
And on her knee before him falling lowe,
But ouerthrew himselfe vnwares, and lower lay.
And lower part did reach to lowest Hell;
Which it suruew'd, as hils doen lower ground;
Doth light the lower world, were halfe yspent,
Of all this lower world, toward his dissolution.
Into a lower roome, and by and by
And forth into the lower parts did pas;
This lower world nigh all to ashes brent,
Which in their lower braunches sung aloud;
So goodly brought them to the lowest staire
Is vndermined from the lowest ground
And lower part did reach to lowest Hell;
Whom fortune hath alreadie laid in lowest seat.
Betwixt the lowest earth and heauens hight,
From lowest Iuniper to Ceder tall,
Like to the balefull house of lowest hell,
And lowest hell, to which I lie most neare,
Downe to her lowest heele, and thereuppon
Euen vnto the lowest and the least.
He humbly louted in meeke lowlinesse,
Of life, which here in lowlinesse ye lead,
As time her taught, in lowly Shepheards weeds,
Vpon a lowly Asse more white then snow,
And ouerflow each plaine and lowly dale:
And to the ground his eyes were lowly bent,
A little lowly Hermitage it was,
Though conquered now he lie on lowly land,
And sitting high; for lowly she did hate:
And falling her before on lowly knee,
And all prostrate vpon the lowly plaine,
The Lyon stoup to him in lowly wise,
With lookes full lowly cast, and gate full slow,
Downe in a darkesome lowly place farre in,
With folded hands and knees full lowly bent
On which they lowly sit, and fitting purpose frame.
Into a pleasant dale, that lowly lay
And lowly did abase their loftie crests
Tho to him louting lowly, did begin
Thus lowly to abase thy beautie bright,
Lowly verse may loftily arise,
That it rebounds against the lowly plaine,
Ruffed of loue, gan lowly to auaile,
Are wont to cleaue vnto the lowly clay,
Lifteth it vp, that else would lowly fall:
Thou a meane Squire, of meeke and lowly place,
Till Trompart lowly to the ground inclind,
And lowly to her lowting thus behight;
Thrise lowted lowly to the noble Mayd,
He louted lowly, as did him becum,
And make them leuell with the lowly plaine:
The hils doe not the lowly dales disdaine;
To serue the lowly vassall of her might,
Him selfe before her feete he lowly threw,
High ouer hilles, and lowly ouer dales,
Which though it on a lowly stalke doe bowre,
And falling lowly at his feet, her bowd
This lowly quiet life, which I inherite here.
Had euer learn'd to loue the lowly things,
Did seeme to ouerlooke the lowly vale;
He lowrd on her with daungerous eyeglaunce;
Shame lowrd, Repentance sigh'd, Reproch did scould;
Before that angry heauens list to lowre,
When so the froward skye began to lowre:
Yet secretly their hoste did on them lowre,
Thereat all Knights gan laugh, and Ladies lowre:
As he, on whom the lucklesse starres did lowre,
Till that th'offended heauens list to lowre
But since faire Sunne hath sperst that lowring clowd,
But with bent lowring browes, as she would threat,
Thrise lowted lowly to the noble Mayd,
And lowly to her lowting thus behight;
And twixt them both was borne the bloudy bold Sans loy.
And on his shield Sans loy in bloudie lines was dyde.
If from their loyall loues he might then moue;
The loyall links of wedlocke did vnbind,
And loyall truth to treason doest incline;
So chast and loyall liu'd, but she would striue
Then loyall loue had royall regiment,
Enlincked fast in wedlockes loyall bond,
With breach of faith and loyaltie vnsound,
My loyalty, not such as it did seeme;
With breach of loue, and loyalty betrayd.
From whose two loynes thou afterwards did rayse
And her lancke loynes vngirt, and brests vnbraste,
About their tender loynes to knit the same;
Yet it to none of all their loynes would fit,
From that vile lozell, which her late offended,
His Lucida, that was full faire and sheene,
Who after long debate, since Lucies time,
Of proud Lucifer', as one of the traine:
And proud Lucifera men did her call,
Of proud Lucifera, and his owne companie.
And bad me call Lucina to me neare.
Lucina came: a manchild forth I brought:
Lucinaes aide: which when they both perceiued,
Then Coyll, and after him good Lucius,
Glad of such lucke, the luckelesse lucky maid,
And though good lucke prolonged hath thy date,
Good lucke presents you with yond louely mayd,
Yet my good lucke he shall not likewise pray;
And often did of loue, and oft of lucke complaine.
And sight of men, since his late luckelesse fray.
Glad of such lucke, the luckelesse lucky maid,
Whose luckelesse riders late were ouerthrowen;
Of luckelesse Marinell Cymodoce.
They met together in that luckelesse glade;
By meanes his leg through his late luckelesse prise,
That to thy blisse I made this luckelesse breach,
But I more fearefull, or more luckie wight,
Whom hauing slaine, through luckles arrowes glau[n]ce
And said, Why Archimago, lucklesse syre,
The lucklesse conflict with the Gyant stout,
In which my Lord my liege doth lucklesse lie,
More lucklesse disauentures did amate:
That oft they did lament his lucklesse state,
Then to thy lucklesse parents did befall:
This lucklesse child, whom thus ye see with bloud defild.
Ah lucklesse babe, borne vnder cruell starre,
He ran on foot, as if in lucklesse warre
Yet now my lucklesse lot doth me constraine
The lucklesse Marinell, lying in deadly swound;
And of his lucklesse lot and cruell loue thus plaind.
But that he yet was sore of his late lucklesse fight.
At last his lucklesse hand he heau'd on hie,
Vnto this houre, this present lucklesse howre,
There did this lucklesse mayd seuen months abide,
This lucklesse Ladie, which now here doth headlesse lie.
As he, on whom the lucklesse starres did lowre,
That he his loue so lucklesse now had lost,
Of all his mischiefe, and late lucklesse smart;
Let them that list, their lucklesse lot deplore;
Mongst which this lucklesse mayd away was lad,
Glad of such lucke, the luckelesse lucky maid,
Vpon the ioynt the lucky steele did light,
Might be my lucky lot; sith all by lot we hold.
The lucky Pylot of her passage sad,
Loue that same other Damzell, Lucy bright,
But Bracidas and Lucy were right glad,
He had two sonnes, whose eldest called Lud
Coulin to make, being eight lugs of grownd;
All wallowd in his owne yet luke-warme blood,
Wyde was the wound, and a large lukewarme flood,
Possessed of sweete sleepe, that luld him soft in swound.
And lull in rugged armes, withouten childish feare.
To lull him soft a sleepe, that by it lay;
And more, to lulle him in his slumber soft,
By this she had him lulled fast a sleepe,
My senses lulled are in slomber of delight.
As lump of lead, and made darke clouds appeare;
Now lyest thou a lumpe of earth forlorne,
Then vp he rose like heauie lumpe of lead,
To sperre the gate; but that same lumpe of clay,
So now all three one sencelesse lumpe remaine,
Did choke the entraunce with a lumpe of sin,
But fell to ground, like to a lumpe of durt;
Full of great lumpes of flesh and gobbets raw,
The lumpish corse vnto the senselesse grownd;
With heauie looke and lumpish pace, that plaine
As if his lungs and lites were nigh a sunder brast.
Lurckt false Duessa secretly vnseene,
Nor draw vnto the lure of his lewd lay,
Whose luring baytes oftimes doe heedlesse harts entyse.
Did closely lurke; yet so true-seeming grace
Or in his wombe might lurke some hidden nest
Do lurke, thou certainly to me areed,
Wherein th'ï¿½gyptian Phao long did lurke
To lurke emongst your Nymphes in secret wize;
To hide th'intent, which in my heart did lurke,
To hide the horrour, which did lurke behinde,
Of Mona, where it lurked in exile;
That as a Snake, still lurked in his wounded mind.
That the rich metall lurked priuily,
Lurking in rockes and caues farre vnder ground,
He, like an Adder, lurking in the weeds,
But like wild beasts lurking in loathsome den,
As lurking from the vew of couetous guest,
And lurkt in rocks and caues long vnespide.
All passers by, to tast their lushious wine,
He shooke off luskishnesse, and courage chill
In this great passion of vnwonted lust,
In wanton lust and lewd embracement:
But he was stout, and lust did now inflame
Whose greedy lust did lacke in greatest store,
From lawlesse lust by wondrous grace
And kindling coles of lust in brutish eye,
When that lewd ribauld with vile lust aduaunst
In chaines of lust and lewd desires ybound,
And to all lawlesse lust encouraged,
At last when lust of meat and drinke was ceast,
Gan burne in filthy lust, and leaping light,
Was giuen all to lust and loose liuing,
And whom I lust, do heape with glory and renowne?
To all licentious lust, and gan exceed
Thy spouse I will her make, if that thou lust,
Ne suffred lust his safetie to betray;
Through vaine illusion of their lust vnclene,
With stings of carnall lust, and strong effort
The secret signes of kindled lust appeare,
Quite molten into lust and pleasure lewd;
Breathing out beastly lust her to defile:
For she was giuen all to fleshly lust,
For this was not to loue, but lust inclind;
Of filthy lust, contrarie vnto kind:
In brutish minds, and filthy lust inflame,
No loue, but brutish lust, that was so beastly tind.
In fleshly lust were mingled both yfere,
